methods.name: General Standart

codes.name: Research purpose
codes.description: states a purpose, problem, objective, or research question

codes.name: Motivation
codes.description: explains why the problem, objective, or research question is important (motivation)

codes.name: Definitions
codes.description: defines jargon, acronyms and key concepts

codes.name: Methodology
codes.description: methodology is appropriate (not necessarily optimal) for stated purpose or questions

codes.name: Data collection
codes.description: describes in detail what, where, when and how data were collected (see the Sampling Supplement)

codes.name: Data analysis description
codes.description: describes in detail how the data were analyzed

codes.name: Statistical assumptions
codes.description: discusses and validates assumptions of any statistical tests used

codes.name: Result presentation
codes.description: present results

codes.name: Result addressing research
codes.description: results directly address research questions

codes.name: Supported claims
codes.description: supports main claims or conclusions with explicit evidence (data/observations) or arguments

codes.name: Results implications
codes.description: discusses implications of the results

codes.name: Study limitations
codes.description: discusses the study's limitations and threats to validity

codes.name: Contribution to BoK
codes.description: contributes in some way to the collective body of knowledge

codes.name: Language misleading
codes.description: language is not misleading; any grammatical problems do not substantially hinder understanding

codes.name: Benefit risk balance
codes.description: balances the study's anticipated benefits with its potential risks or harms, minimizing risk or harm wherever possible (see the ethics supplements for studies with Human Participants or Secondary Data)

codes.name: Visualizations
codes.description: visualizations/graphs are not misleading (see the Information Visualization Supplement)

codes.name: Related work synthesis
codes.description: summarizes and synthesizes a reasonable selection of related work

codes.name: Relation with related work
codes.description: clearly describes relationship between contribution(s) and related work

codes.name: Epistemological stance
codes.description: states epistemological stance (e.g. post-positivism, interpretivism, critical realism)

codes.name: Statistical power/saturation
codes.description: appropriate statistical power (for quantitative work) or saturation (for qualitative work

codes.name: Limitations mitigation
codes.description: reasonable attempts to investigate or mitigate limitations

codes.name: Study realism
codes.description: discusses study’s realism, assumptions and sensitivity of the results to its realism/assumptions

codes.name: Recommendation providing
codes.description: provides plausibly useful interpretations or recommendations for practice, education or research

codes.name: Open sharing
codes.description: openly shares data and materials to the extent possible within practical and ethical limits (see the Open Science Supplement)

codes.name: Presentation
codes.description: concise, precise, well-organized and easy-to-read presentation

codes.name: Visualizations for argumentation
codes.description: visualizations (e.g. graphs, diagrams, tables) advance the paper’s arguments or contribution

codes.name: Researchers roles
codes.description: clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the researchers (i.e. who did what?)

codes.name: Auto-reflection
codes.description: provides an auto-reflection or assessment of the authors’ own work (e.g. lessons learned)

codes.name: Multiple raters use
codes.description: uses multiple raters for any subjective judgments (see the IRR/IRA Supplement)

codes.name: Multiple data collection
codes.description: applies two or more data collection or analysis strategies to the same research question (see the Multimethodology Standard)

codes.name: Multiple epistemological perspectives
codes.description: approaches the same research question(s) from multiple epistemological perspectives

codes.name: Research methodology innovation
codes.description: innovates on research methodology while completing an empirical study

invalidCriticisms: Setting arbitrary minimum sample sizes or other data requirements, based on neither power analysis nor theoretical saturation
Stating that a study:

(i) lacks detail without enumerating missing details; (ii) is of low quality without explaining specific problems; or (iii) is not new without providing citations to published studies that make practically identical contributions.
Rejecting a study because it replicates or reproduces existing work
Cross-paradigmatic criticism (e.g. attacking an interpretivist study for not conforming to positivist norms).
Criticizing a study for limitations intrinsic to that kind of study or the methodology used (e.g. attacking a case study for low generalizability)
Rejecting a study because the reviewer would have used a different methodology or design
Rejecting a study because it reports negative results

methods.name: Engineering research (Design Science)

codes.name: Artifact description
codes.description: describes the proposed artifact in adequate detail

codes.name: Usefulness
codes.description: justifies the need for, usefulness of, or relevance of the proposed artifact

codes.name: Conceptual evaluation
codes.description: conceptually evaluates the artifact; discusses its strengths, weaknesses and limitations

codes.name: Alternatives
codes.description: EITHER: discusses state-of-art alternatives (and their strengths, weaknesses and limitations) OR: explains why no state-of-art alternatives exist OR: provides compelling argument that direct comparisons are impractical

codes.name: Empirical evaluation
codes.description: Empirically evaluates the proposed artifact using action research,in which the researchers intervene a real organization using the artifact, a case study in which a real organization uses the artifact without researcher intervention, a controlled experiment in which human participants use the artifact, a simulation in which the artifact is used in an artificial environment, or another method for which a clear and convincing rationale is provided

codes.name: Methodology
codes.description: clearly indicates the empirical methodology being used (e.g. action research, controlled experiment)

codes.name: Comparation
codes.description: EITHER: empirically compares the artifact to one or more state-of-the-art alternative artifacts OR: empirically compares the artifact to one or more state - of -the - art benchmarks OR: provides a clear and convincing rationale for why comparative evaluation is impractical

codes.name: Assumptions
codes.description: assumptions (if any) are explicit; do not contradict each other or the contribution's goals; plausibly hold for the evaluation subjects

codes.name: Consistent notation
codes.description: uses notation consistently (if any notation is used)

codes.name: Theoretical basis
codes.description: reviews the theoretical basis of the artifact

codes.name: Arguments
codes.description: provides correctness arguments of the key analytical and theoretical contributions (e.g. theorems, complexity analyses, mathematical proofs)

codes.name: Examples
codes.description: includes one or more running examples to elucidate the artifact

codes.name: Industry context
codes.description: evaluates the artifact in an industry-relevant context (e.g. widely used open-source projects, professional programmers)

codes.name: Replication package
codes.description: provides a replication package including datasets and analytical scripts and EITHER a comprehensive description of the artifact OR source code if artifact is virtual

codes.name: Contribution to understanding
codes.description: contributes to our collective understanding of design practices or principles

codes.name: Innovation
codes.description: presents ground-breaking innovations with obvious real-world benefits

invalidCriticisms: The paper does not report as ambitious an empirical study as other predominately empirical papers. The more innovative the artifact and more comprehensive the conceptual evaluation, the less we should expect from the empirical study.

Too few experimental subjects (e.g. the source code used to evaluate a static analysis technique) if few subjects are available in the contribution's domain or the experimental evaluation is part of a more comprehensive validation strategy (e.g. formal arguments). Other criteria, such as the variety, realism, availability, and scale of the subjects, should also be considered to assess the quality of the evaluation.
No replication package, if there are clear, convincing practical or ethical reasons preventing artifact disclosure.

The artifact is not experimentally compared with related approaches that are not publicly available. In other words, before saying "you should have compared this against X, make sure X is actually available and functional"

This is not the first known solution to the identified problem. The novelty of the paper can be in how it achieves scalability, better performance on specific classes of problems, applicability to realistic systems, stronger theoretical guarantees, or other aspects of improvement. Proposed artifacts should outperform existing artifacts on some dimension(s).
The contribution is not technically complicated. What matters is that it works. Unnecessary complexity is undesirable.

methods.name: Action research

codes.name: Case justification
codes.description: justifies the selection of the case or site that was studied

codes.name: Site description
codes.description: describes the site of the intervention(s) in rich detail

codes.name: Intervention(s)
codes.description: describes the intervention(s) in detail

codes.name: Relationship
codes.description: describes the relationship between the researcher and the host organization

codes.name: Research dimension
codes.description: describes the longitudinal dimension of the research design (including the length of the study)

codes.name: Interventions
codes.description: describes the interactions between researcher(s) and host organization(s)---what the interventions were, who intervened and with which part of the organization, as well as the outcome of the interventions

codes.name: Determination of interventions
codes.description: describes how interventions were determined (by management, researchers, or participative/co- determination process)

codes.name: Research cycles
codes.description: explains research cycles or phases, if any, and their relationship to the intervention(s)

codes.name: Evaluation of interventions
codes.description: explains how the interventions are evaluated

codes.name: Reactions to interventions
codes.description: reports participant or stakeholder reactions to interventions

codes.name: Evidence chain
codes.description: presents a clear chain of evidence from observations to findings

codes.name: Lessons learned
codes.description: reports lessons learned by the organization

codes.name: Biases
codes.description: researchers reflect on their own possible biases

codes.name: Supplemental materials
codes.description: provides supplemental materials such as interview guide(s), coding schemes, coding examples, decision rules, or extended chain-of-evidence tables

codes.name: Direct quotations
codes.description: uses direct quotations extensively

codes.name: Results validation
codes.description: validates results using member checking, dialogical interviewing4, feedback from non-participant practitioners or research audits of coding by advisors or other researchers

codes.name: Findings
codes.description: findings plausibly transferable to other contexts

codes.name: Data triangulation
codes.description: triangulation across quantitative and qualitative data

codes.name: Researchers triangulation
codes.description: research team with triangulation across researchers (to mitigate researcher bias)

invalidCriticisms: The findings and insights are not valid because the research intervened in the context. Though reflexivity is crucial, the whole point of action research is to introduce a change and observe how participants react.

This is merely consultancy or an experience report. Systematic observation and reflection should not be dismissed as consultancy or experience reports. Inversely, consultancy or experiences should not be falsely presented as action research.
Lack of quantitative data; causal analysis; objectivity, internal validity, reliability, or generalizability.
Sample not representative; lack of generalizability; generalizing from one organization.
Lack of replicability or reproducibility; not releasing transcripts.
Lack of control group or experimental protocols. An action research study is not an experiment.
